metadata.title: Learning from discriminative feature feedback
metadata.author: Sanjoy Dasgupta, Sivan Sabato, Nicholas Roberts, Akansha Dey
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract:
We consider the problem of learning a multi-class classifier from labels as well as simple explanations that we call
. We show that such discriminative features explanations can be provided whenever the target concept is a decision tree, or can be expressed as a particular type of multi-class DNF formula. We present an efficient online algorithm for learning from such feedback and we give tight bounds on the number of mistakes made during the learning process. These bounds depend only on the representation size of the target concept and not on the overall number of available features, which could be infinite. We also demonstrate the learning procedure experimentally.

summary: Communication between humans and machine learning systems has typically been restricted to labels alone.
We show that the algorithm provably converges to the correct concept, and we provide a tight mistake bound on the total number of errors it makes over the lifetime of the learning process.
Earlier mistake bounds for online learning, such as those for the Perceptron and Winnow algorithms, had some dependence on the number of features.
> Correct class: fish – In addition, the labeler provides a distinguishing feature between the instance being classified and the instance that the learner suggested as a similar example.

Our assumptions posit that there is some representation of the domain as purely-labeled sets that can be separated by single features, and that this representation is the one used implicitly by the teacher when providing feedback to the learner.
